Federated Learning for Sparse Principal Component Analysis

Abstract

In the rapidly evolving realm of machine learning, algorithm effectiveness often faces limitations due to data quality and availability. Traditional approaches grapple with data sharing due to legal and privacy concerns. The federated learning framework addresses this challenge. Federated learning is a decentralized approach where model training occurs on client sides, preserving privacy by keeping data localized. Instead of sending raw data to a central server, only model updates are exchanged, enhancing data security. We apply this framework to Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA) in this work. SPCA aims to attain sparse component loadings while maximizing data variance for improved interpretability. Beside the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} norm regularization term in conventional SPCA, we add a smoothing function to facilitate gradient-based optimization methods. Moreover, in order to improve computational efficiency, we introduce a least squares approximation to original SPCA. This enables analytic solutions on the optimization processes, leading to substantial computational improvements. Within the federated framework, we formulate SPCA as a consensus optimization problem, which can be solved using the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM). Our extensive experiments involve both IID and non-IID random features across various data owners. Results on synthetic and public datasets affirm the efficacy of our federated SPCA approach.

Index Terms:
ADMM, Consensus Learning, Federated Learning, Sparse Principal Component Analysis

I Introduction

In the rapidly evolving field of machine learning, the effectiveness of algorithms often hinges on the quantity, quality and accessibility of data. Unfortunately, due to legal and privacy concerns, data sharing for the purpose of enhancing machine learning is typically prohibited. To address this challenge, the Federated Learning (FL) framework was introduced [1]. Federated learning represents a decentralized approach, where model training takes place on client-side devices, ensuring privacy by keeping data localized. Instead of transmitting raw data to a central server, only model updates are exchanged, thereby bolstering data security. This constitutes a distributed learning process.

In general, many machine learning tasks can be framed as optimization problems, and distributed optimization techniques have been well-developed. It is inherent in the nature of the federated learning framework to have applications across various machine learning algorithms, including linear and nonlinear support vector machines, as well as deep learning. In this context, we will introduce two innovative approaches: Federated Smoothing Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FSSPCA) and Federated Approximation Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FASPCA). These methodologies have been specifically crafted to tackle the challenge of Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA) within a distributed framework.

Principal Component Analysis (PCA), introduced by Pearson [2] in 1901, has been extensively used in various applications, from dimension reduction to anomaly detection [3]. The goal of PCA is to find an orthogonal basis that maximizes the variance of the original data when projected onto this basis. Formatting this as an optimization problem, we have

maxw∈ℝd×rsubscriptwsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\displaystyle\max_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}} ‖Aw‖F2superscriptsubscriptnormAw𝐹2\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\|_{F}^{2}
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. w⊤​w=I,superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I},

where A∈ℝn×dAsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\textbf{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} is a mean-centered dataset with n𝑛n instances and d𝑑d features and ∥⋅∥F\|\cdot\|_{F} represents the Frobenius norm of a matrix. The matrix w∈ℝd×rwsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r} consists of r𝑟r principal components, which are the eigenvectors corresponding to the r𝑟r largest eigenvalues of the covariance matrix of A. Alternatively, PCA can be reformulated into a minimization problem:

minw∈ℝd×rsubscriptwsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}} ‖A−Aww⊤‖F2superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop𝐹2\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. w⊤​w=I.superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I}.

This reformulation can be interpreted as minimization of the reconstruction error, which aims to represent data in fewer dimensions, while still approximating the original data as closely as possible.

However, traditional PCA often yields dense component loadings, making the results difficult to interpret. To address this issue, Sparse PCA (SPCA) was proposed [4], aiming to find loadings that are more interpretable due to their sparsity.

In addition to its conventional applications, PCA is also harnessed in FL frameworks to enable collaborative computation without data centralization [5]. SPCA has yet to be fully adapted and studied within this emerging framework, suggesting a novel direction for advancement. In this work, we focus on a distributed setting in which various data owners aim to jointly train a model without sharing their own data with each other. Suppose that the objective function f​(w)𝑓wf(\textbf{w}) can be decomposed into K𝐾K parts as f​(w)=∑i=1Kfi​(w)𝑓wsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑓𝑖wf(\textbf{w})=\sum_{i=1}^{K}f_{i}(\textbf{w}), where K𝐾K is the number of data owners and each fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is a local objective function, which involves only the data of the i𝑖ith owner. The minimization of f​(w)𝑓wf(\textbf{w}) can be reformulated as the following global variable consensus optimization problem [6]:

minw1,⋯,wK,zsubscriptsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾z\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K},\textbf{z}} ∑i=1Kfi​(wi)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptw𝑖\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}f_{i}(\textbf{w}_{i})
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. wi=z,∀i,subscriptw𝑖zfor-all𝑖\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{z},\forall i,

where z is the common global variable and each wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} is the local variable for each data owner. In the framework of FL, the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm, a widely adopted approach in such context, can be employed.

The ADMM iterative algorithm within the framework of FL consists of two parts: the master’s and the workers’. Suppose that there exists a central server, called the master, responsible for updating the global variable z and integrating all local variables wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i}. Each data owner employs a device known as the worker, tasked with updating the local variable wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} by minimizing the objective fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} using its own data. Following the update of wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i}, each worker sends the locally updated variable wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} to the master. Consequently, the master integrates wi,∀isubscriptw𝑖for-all𝑖\textbf{w}_{i},\forall i, to update z, and then distributes the globally updated parameter z to all workers. The goal of this iterative process is to compute the sparse loadings within the FL framework.

II RELATED WORK

II-A Sparse Principal Component Analysis

In recent years, numerous approaches for SPCA have been introduced [7]. Inspired by lasso regression, Jolliffe et al. [8] proposed SCOTLASS, which added an ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm term to the original PCA problem. Unlike SCOTLASS, Zou et al. [4] added an ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm term or an elastic net term by

minw,v∈ℝd×rsubscriptwvsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w},\textbf{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}} ‖A−Awv⊤‖F2+∑i=1r(λ​‖vi‖22+γi​‖vi‖1)superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwvtop𝐹2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟𝜆superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑖22subscript𝛾𝑖subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑖1\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{v}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{r}\left(\lambda\|v_{i}\|_{2}^{2}+\gamma_{i}\|v_{i}\|_{1}\right) (1)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. w⊤​w=I,superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I},

where A∈ℝn×dAsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\textbf{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} is a mean-centered dataset of n𝑛n instances with d𝑑d features, r𝑟r is the number of desired loadings, visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} is the i𝑖ith column of v, and λ,γi>0𝜆subscript𝛾𝑖0\lambda,\gamma_{i}>0 are trade-off parameters. They solved this problem by iterating the sub-problems of w and v alternately. One advantage of this approach is that it decomposes the orthogonality constraint and the non-smooth ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm term into two sub-problems. Thus, each sub-problem is easier to solve than the original problem. Some methods tackle SPCA by relying on power methods. Journee et al. [9] proposed the generalized power method (Gpower) to extract a single sparse dominant principal component or more components at once with the ℓ0subscriptℓ0\ell_{0}-norm or the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm. Ge et al. [10] proposed distributed privacy-preserving SPCA to compute SPCA in a distributed optimization framework by the power iteration with differential privacy.

II-B ADMM

The Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) is an optimization method commonly used in federated learning. It was first proposed in the 1970s by Glowinski [11] and Gabay et al. [12]. In 2011, Boyd et al. [6] proposed a detailed review of this algorithm, making it widely adopted in decentralized machine learning [13, 14, 15]. Furthermore, by combining cryptographic tools such as multiparty computation [16, 17], and zero-knowledge proof [18], the ADMM algorithm can protect data privacy when applied to federated learning models [19, 20]

Some studies employed the ADMM algorithm on sparse PCA. Ma and Shiqian [21] solved the DSPCA by the ADMM algorithm. Vu et al. [22] viewed the SPCA problem as an optimization problem on the Fantope and then used the ADMM algorithm to solve it. Instead of the convex penalty term ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm, Hajinezhad and Hong [23] used non-convex penalties to obtain sparse loading by the non-convex ADMM algorithm. Tan et al. [24] considered the SPCA problem as an optimization problem on the Stiefel manifold and then used the ADMM algorithm to solve it. Despite the widespread use of ADMM in SPCA, these studies have not yet ventured into its application within the context of federated learning.

II-C Smoothing function

When dealing with optimization problems, deriving closed-form solutions is often not practical for the majority of cases. In such scenarios, it is a common approach to use gradient-based methods such as Newton’s method, stochastic gradient descent, and Adam method [25]. Nevertheless, if the problem lacks differentiability, it remains unfeasible to employ these gradient-based methods. For example, because of the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm, problem (1) is not differentiable at 0. To address this issue, a common approach is to employ a smoothing function as a replacement for the non-differentiable part [26, 27, 28]. This technique is also widely adopted in the field of machine learning and deep learning. For instance, the sigmoid function is often used to substitute the rectified linear unit [29, 30]. However, to our knowledge, using smoothing functions to replace the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm in the SPCA has not been explored. In our proposed method, we employ a smoothing function to substitute the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm, thus enabling the utilization of gradient-based methods to the SPCA problem.

III Proposed model

III-A Federated Smoothing Sparse Principal Component Analysis

Let A=[A1,⋯,AK]⊤∈ℝn×dAsuperscriptsuperscriptA1⋯superscriptA𝐾topsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\textbf{A}=[\textbf{A}^{1},\cdots,\textbf{A}^{K}]^{\top}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} be a mean-centered dataset comprising n𝑛n instances with d𝑑d features, stored separately in the K𝐾K distinct devices. Each worker can only access its own local data, Ai∈ℝni×dsuperscriptA𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑑\textbf{A}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}\times d}, where nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} represents the number of instances in the dataset for each worker. Throughout the computation, the workers can only share model parameters but not data by uploading the locally updated parameter to the central server (master). In this work, we aim to solve the following optimization problem to find sparse loadings of the dataset A:

minw∈ℝd×rsubscriptwsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}} ‖A−Aww⊤‖F2+λ​‖w‖1superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop𝐹2𝜆subscriptnormw1\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{w}\|_{1} (2)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. w⊤​w=I,superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I},

where r𝑟r is the number of desired loadings, λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 is a trade-off parameter, Aww⊤superscriptAwwtop\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top} is the reconstructed data using w, and ∥⋅∥1\|\cdot\|_{1} represents the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm for matrix as‖w‖1=∑i,j|wi​j|subscriptnormw1subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗\|\textbf{w}\|_{1}=\sum_{i,j}|w_{ij}|.

The first term of (2) is to minimize the reconstruction error, and the second term is to pursue the sparse representation through the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm, with the constraint of maintaining the orthonormality of the loading. However, the orthonormality constraint is challenging. Following Tan et al. [24], we modify it by restricting w to the Stiefel manifold,

ℳr={w∈ℝd×r|w⊤​w=I},subscriptℳ𝑟conditional-setwsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\mathcal{M}_{r}=\{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}|\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I}\},

which is the set of d𝑑d-by-r𝑟r orthonormal matrices to simplify the problem. Subsequently, we can reformulate (2) as follows

minw∈ℳr⁡‖A−Aww⊤‖F2+λ​‖w‖1.subscriptwsubscriptℳ𝑟superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop𝐹2𝜆subscriptnormw1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}}\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{w}\|_{1}. (3)

Though, the orthonormality constraint of (3) and the non-smooth ‖w‖1subscriptnormw1\|\textbf{w}\|_{1} term still remain challenging in solving the problem. Moreover, since each worker cannot share their own dataset AisuperscriptA𝑖\textbf{A}^{i} with each other, it suffices to reformulate (3) in a distributed form. Note that ‖A−Aww⊤‖F2superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop𝐹2\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2} can be decompose into K𝐾K parts by

‖A−Aww⊤‖F2=∑i=1K‖Ai−Ai​ww⊤‖F2.superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop𝐹2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖superscriptA𝑖superscriptwwtop𝐹2\displaystyle\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{K}\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}. (4)

Hence, we can reformulate (3) as a consensus optimization problem,

minw1,⋯,wK∈ℳrsubscriptsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾subscriptℳ𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}} ∑i=1K‖Ai−Ai​wi​wi⊤‖F2+λ​‖z‖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖superscriptA𝑖subscriptw𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top𝐹2𝜆subscriptnormz1\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{z}\|_{1} (5)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. wi=z,∀i,subscriptw𝑖zfor-all𝑖\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{z},\forall i,

where w1,⋯,wKsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K} are parameters for each worker and z∈ℝd×rzsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\textbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r} is the consensus parameter. With this formulation, we can adopt the algorithm in Tan et al. [24].

However, we observe that the algorithm struggles to converge when applied to the federated learning problem. As shown in Fig. 4a, the objective function exhibits significant fluctuations during the iterative process. To solve this problem, we introduce the Federated Smoothing SPCA (FSSPCA) in the following.

Inspired by Saheya et al. [27], we add an ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm smoothing function r​(⋅)𝑟⋅r(\cdot) to problem (5)

minw1,⋯,wK∈ℳrsubscriptsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾subscriptℳ𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}} ∑i=1K(‖Ai−Ai​wi​wi⊤‖F2+λ1​r​(wi))+λ2​‖z‖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖superscriptA𝑖subscriptw𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top𝐹2subscript𝜆1𝑟subscriptw𝑖subscript𝜆2subscriptnormz1\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}\left(\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda_{1}r(\textbf{w}_{i})\right)+\lambda_{2}\|\textbf{z}\|_{1} (6)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. wi=z,∀i,subscriptw𝑖zfor-all𝑖\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{z},\forall i,

where λ1,λ2≥0subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆20\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}\geq 0 are the trade-off parameters. Given a real matrix X, the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm of X is the sum of all absolute values of entries in X. Therefore, it is reasonable to construct the smoothing function r​(⋅)𝑟⋅r(\cdot) using an absolute value smoothing function ψ​(⋅)𝜓⋅\psi(\cdot). Following Saheya et al. [27, 28], we use r​(X)=∑i,jψ​(xi,j)𝑟Xsubscript𝑖𝑗𝜓subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗r(\textbf{X})=\sum_{i,j}\psi(x_{i,j}) due to its accuracy and computational efficiency, as described by the following equation:

ψ​(xi,j)={xi,jifxi,j≥μ2xi,j2μ+μ4if−μ2<xi,j<μ2−xi,jifxi,j≤−μ2,𝜓subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗casessubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗ifsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝜇2superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗2𝜇𝜇4if𝜇2subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝜇2subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗ifsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝜇2\displaystyle\psi(x_{i,j})=\left\{\begin{array}[]{rcl}x_{i,j}&\mbox{if}&x_{i,j}\geq\frac{\mu}{2}\\ \frac{x_{i,j}^{2}}{\mu}+\frac{\mu}{4}&\mbox{if}&\frac{-\mu}{2}<x_{i,j}<\frac{\mu}{2}\\ -x_{i,j}&\mbox{if}&x_{i,j}\leq\frac{-\mu}{2}\end{array}\right., (10)

where μ𝜇\mu is a similarity parameter for ψ​(xi,j)𝜓subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗\psi(x_{i,j}) such that limμ→0ψ​(xi,j)→|xi,j|→subscript→𝜇0𝜓subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗\lim_{\mu\to 0}\psi(x_{i,j})\to|x_{i,j}|. In our experiments, we set μ𝜇\mu to 10−3superscript10310^{-3}. As depicted in Fig. 1, when xi,jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗x_{i,j} is closed to zero, the smoothing function ψ​(xi,j)𝜓subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗\psi(x_{i,j}) closely approximates the absolute value of xi,jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗x_{i,j}, providing a smoothed representation.

We can observe that the consensus optimization formulation (6) separates the orthonormality constraint and the non-smooth term into two sub-problems, making each more accessible. Subsequently, following Boyd et al. [6], we use the ADMM algorithm to solve this problem. By introducing a dual variable ui∈ℝd×rsubscriptu𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\textbf{u}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r} for the equality constraint, we obtain an augmented Lagrangian:

where ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 is a penalty parameter. The general ADMM algorithm for FSSPCA is outlined in Algorithm 1. The algorithm minimizes ℒρS​(⋅)superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌𝑆⋅\mathcal{L}_{\rho}^{S}(\cdot), and employs the function qf​(⋅)qf⋅\text{qf}(\cdot), which denotes the Q factor in the QR decomposition, to ensure the orthogonality of the loadings in the last step.

Next, let us introduce how to compute wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} and z in Algorithm 1. In the next subsection, we introduce how to update wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} (local primal update) in Algorithm 1.

III-B Line-search method on the Stiefel Manifold

For each worker, with fixed uisubscriptu𝑖\textbf{u}_{i} and z, the optimization of ℒρS​({wi,ui}i=1K,z)superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌𝑆superscriptsubscriptsubscriptw𝑖subscriptu𝑖𝑖1𝐾z\mathcal{L}_{\rho}^{S}(\{\textbf{w}_{i},\textbf{u}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K},\textbf{z}) over wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} is given by

minwi∈ℳrsubscriptsubscriptw𝑖subscriptℳ𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{i}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}} ‖Ai−Ai​wi​wi⊤‖F2+λ1​r​(wi)superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖superscriptA𝑖subscriptw𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top𝐹2subscript𝜆1𝑟subscriptw𝑖\displaystyle\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda_{1}r(\textbf{w}_{i}) (14)
+⟨ui,wi⟩+ρ2​‖wi−z‖F2.subscriptu𝑖subscriptw𝑖𝜌2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptw𝑖z𝐹2\displaystyle+\langle\textbf{u}_{i},\textbf{w}_{i}\rangle+\frac{\rho}{2}\|\textbf{w}_{i}-\textbf{z}\|_{F}^{2}.

Following Tan et al. [24], (14) can be solved using the line-search method on the Stiefel Manifold.

The primary objective of the line search method is to find a descent direction in which our objective function decreases. A direct approach is to take the opposite direction of the gradient as the descent direction. However, since the objective function (14) is restricted to the Stiefel manifold, its gradient cannot be directly computed through partial differentiation.

To address optimization on the Stiefel manifold ℳrsubscriptℳ𝑟\mathcal{M}_{r}, we introduce some geometries over the Stiefel manifold ℳrsubscriptℳ𝑟\mathcal{M}_{r}. First, the tangent space to ℳrsubscriptℳ𝑟\mathcal{M}_{r} at w∈ℳrwsubscriptℳ𝑟\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}, denoted by Tw​ℳrsubscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}, is defined as

Tw​ℳr={z∈ℝd×r|z⊤​w+w⊤​z=0}.subscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟conditional-setzsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟superscriptztopwsuperscriptwtopz0\displaystyle T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}=\{\textbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}|\textbf{z}^{\top}\textbf{w}+\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{z}=\textbf{0}\}.

Given a smooth function f𝑓f on Euclidean space, let f¯¯𝑓\bar{f} denote the restriction of f𝑓f to the Stiefel manifold. Define sym(A) = 12​(A+A⊤)12AsuperscriptAtop\frac{1}{2}(\textbf{A}+\textbf{A}^{\top}), for any square matrix A. Suppose we have the gradient ∇f​(w)∇𝑓w\nabla f(\textbf{w}) of f𝑓f at w∈ℳrwsubscriptℳ𝑟\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}. Then the gradient of f¯(W)\bar{f}(\textbf{W)}, denoted by gradf​(w)𝑓wf(\textbf{w}), is equal to the orthogonal projection of ∇f​(w)∇𝑓w\nabla f(\textbf{w}) onto Tw​ℳrsubscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}, that is,

grad​f​(w)=PTw​ℳr​(∇f​(w)),grad𝑓wsubscript𝑃subscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟∇𝑓w\displaystyle\text{grad}f(\textbf{w})=P_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}}(\nabla f(\textbf{w})), (15)

where PTw​ℳrsubscript𝑃subscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟P_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}} is denoted the orthogonal projection function onto Tw​ℳrsubscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r} at w∈ℳrwsubscriptℳ𝑟\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r} by

PTw​ℳr​(X)=X−w sym​(w⊤​X),subscript𝑃subscript𝑇wsubscriptℳ𝑟XXw symsuperscriptwtopX\displaystyle P_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}}(\textbf{X})=\textbf{X}-\textbf{w}\text{ sym}(\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{X}), (16)

for any X∈ℝd×rXsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑟\textbf{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}.

After obtaining the gradient of the objective function, which is restricted to the Stiefel manifold, we can proceed to construct the descent direction 𝜻=−grad​f​(w)𝜻grad𝑓w\boldsymbol{\zeta}=-\text{grad}f(\textbf{w}). Additionally, the use of conjugate gradient [24, 31] can improve the convergence speed at workers’ stage. However, the increase of local updates might escalate the divergence between the resultant local models at the workers’ stage before they are averaged [32]. Therefore, for stability, we still use the opposite gradient as the descent direction.

With step size θ𝜃\theta, we can move w along the descent direction 𝜻𝜻\boldsymbol{\zeta} as wn​e​x​t=w+θ​𝜻subscriptw𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡w𝜃𝜻\textbf{w}_{next}=\textbf{w}+\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta}. Unlike the optimization in the Euclidean space, the update process w requires ensuring that wn​e​x​tsubscriptw𝑛𝑒𝑥𝑡\textbf{w}_{next} lies within the confines of the Stiefel manifold. To achieve this, we employ the Retraction mapping to project it onto the manifold by

Rw​(θ​𝜻)=qf​(w+θ​𝜻),subscript𝑅w𝜃𝜻qfw𝜃𝜻\displaystyle R_{\textbf{w}}(\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta})=\text{qf}(\textbf{w}+\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta}), (17)

where qf​(⋅)qf⋅\text{qf}(\cdot) denotes the Q factor in the QR decomposition ensuring the orthonormality.

Finally, following Ring and Wirth [33], we choose the step size θ𝜃\theta satisfying the strong Wolfe conditions

f​(Rw​(θ​𝜻))≤f​(w)+c1​θ​⟨grad​f​(w),𝜻⟩,𝑓subscript𝑅w𝜃𝜻𝑓wsubscript𝑐1𝜃grad𝑓w𝜻\displaystyle f(R_{\textbf{w}}(\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta}))\leq f(\textbf{w})+c_{1}\theta\langle\text{grad}f(\textbf{w}),\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle, (18)
|⟨grad​f​(Rw),𝜻⟩|≤−c2​⟨grad​f​(w),𝜻⟩,grad𝑓subscript𝑅w𝜻subscript𝑐2grad𝑓w𝜻\displaystyle|\langle\text{grad}f(R_{\textbf{w}}),\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle|\leq-c_{2}\langle\text{grad}f(\textbf{w}),\boldsymbol{\zeta}\rangle, (19)

where 0<c1<c2<10subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐210<c_{1}<c_{2}<1. Alternatively, in pursuit of simplicity, one can follow Absil et al. [31] to choose a step size that fulfills the Armijo condition (18).

III-C Deflation method for FSSPCA

FSSPCA can compute multiple loadings simultaneously. However, for the sake of completeness, we further introduce the method of computing additional r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} loadings, considering the existence of r1subscript𝑟1r_{1} loadings, without the necessity of recomputing all of them. Drawing upon the deflation technique for SPCA proposed by Mackey [34], we outline the deflation scheme in Algorithm 4.

Suppose we have r1subscript𝑟1r_{1} loadings {zi}i=1r−1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptz𝑖𝑖1𝑟1\{\textbf{z}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r-1} and intend to compute additional r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} loadings, the problem is formulated as

minw1,⋯,wK∈ℳr2subscriptsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾subscriptℳsubscript𝑟2\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K}\in\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}} ∑i=1K(‖Ai−Ai​wi​wi⊤‖F2+λ1​r​(wi))+λ2​‖z‖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖superscriptA𝑖subscriptw𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top𝐹2subscript𝜆1𝑟subscriptw𝑖subscript𝜆2subscriptnormz1\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}\left(\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda_{1}r(\textbf{w}_{i})\right)+\lambda_{2}\|\textbf{z}\|_{1} (20)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. wi⊤​Gwi=I and wi=z,∀i,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptw𝑖topsubscriptGw𝑖subscriptI and w𝑖zfor-all𝑖\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{G}\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{I}\text{ and }\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{z},\ \forall i,

where G=∏i=1r1(I−zi​zi⊤)∈ℝd×dGsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1subscript𝑟1Isubscriptz𝑖superscriptsubscriptz𝑖topsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\textbf{G}=\prod_{i=1}^{r_{1}}(\textbf{I}-\textbf{z}_{i}\textbf{z}_{i}^{\top})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} lie in the orthogonal complement space of {zi}i=1r1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptz𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑟1\{\textbf{z}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r_{1}}. Because of the orthogonal complement space G, the objective function (20) is actually restricted to the generalized Stiefel manifold ℳr2Gsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2G\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}},

ℳr2G={w∈ℝd×r2|w⊤​Gw=I},superscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2Gconditional-setwsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑟2superscriptwtopGwI\displaystyle\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}=\{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r_{2}}|\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{G}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I}\},

which is the set of d𝑑d-by-r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} G-orthogonal matrices. By restricting to ℳr2Gsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2G\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}, we can ensure that the new loadings {zi}i=r1+1r1+r2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptz𝑖𝑖subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2\{\textbf{z}_{i}\}_{i=r_{1}+1}^{r_{1}+r_{2}} must be orthogonal to the existing loadings.

Considering the difference between the Stiefel manifold ℳrsubscriptℳ𝑟\mathcal{M}_{r} and the generalized Stiefel manifold ℳr2Gsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2G\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}, we extend Algorithm 3 to fit the deflation scenario. First, the tangent space to ℳr2Gsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2G\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}} at w∈ℳr2Gwsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2G\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}, denoted by Tw​ℳr2Gsubscript𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2GT_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}, is defined as

Tw​ℳr2G={z∈ℝd×r2|z⊤​Gw+w⊤​Gz=0}.subscript𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2Gconditional-setzsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑟2superscriptztopGwsuperscriptwtopGz0\displaystyle T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}=\{\textbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r_{2}}|\textbf{z}^{\top}\textbf{G}\textbf{w}+\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{G}\textbf{z}=\textbf{0}\}.

Then the orthogonal projection operator onto Tw​ℳr2Gsubscript𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2GT_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}, denoted by PTw​ℳr2Gsubscript𝑃subscript𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2GP_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}}, is gien by

PTw​ℳr2G​(z)=z−w sym​(w⊤​Gz).subscript𝑃subscript𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptℳsubscript𝑟2Gzzw symsuperscriptwtopGz\displaystyle P_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r_{2}}^{\textbf{G}}}(\textbf{z})=\textbf{z}-\textbf{w}\text{ sym}(\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{G}\textbf{z}). (21)

Moreover, the retraction for the generalized Stiefel manifold is modified as

RwG​(θ​𝜻)=G−1​qf​(G​(w+θ​𝜻)).superscriptsubscript𝑅wG𝜃𝜻superscriptG1qfGw𝜃𝜻\displaystyle R_{\textbf{w}}^{\textbf{G}}(\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta})=\sqrt{\textbf{G}}^{-1}\text{qf}\left(\sqrt{\textbf{G}}(\textbf{w}+\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta})\right). (22)

Nevertheless, when computing (22), we require GG\sqrt{\textbf{G}} and G−1superscriptG1\sqrt{\textbf{G}}^{-1}, which may be computationally expensive for large d𝑑d. To address this problem, Sato and Aihara [35] proposed the Cholesky QR-based retraction as shown in Algorithm 5.

Thus, replacing the projection in Algorithm 3 with (21) and retraction with Algorithm 5, we manage to extend Algorithm 3 from the Stiefel manifold to the generalized Stiefel manifold.

III-D Federated Approximation Sparse Principal Component Analysis

In the previous subsection, we introduced how to tackle the conventional SPCA problem within the federated learning system. However, we observed that employing gradient-based methods to compute r𝑟r loadings simultaneously could incur significant computational costs. Regarding the scenarios that only a single or the first few loadings are desired, we propose an alternative approach using a least squares approximation to alleviate the computational burden. The problem is formulated as

minw∈ℝd×1subscriptwsuperscriptℝ𝑑1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1}} ‖A−Aww⊤‖22+λ​‖w‖1superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop22𝜆subscriptnormw1\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{w}\|_{1} (23)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. w⊤​w=1,superscriptwtopw1\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=1,

where λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 is a trade-off parameter, and w∈ℝd×1wsuperscriptℝ𝑑1\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1} is the desired loading. Inspired by Lee et al. [3, 36], we propose the Federated Approximation SPCA (FASPCA) to solve this problem. Following Yang [37], we utilize the projection approximation technique to transform (23) into the subsequent form,

minw∈ℝd×1subscriptwsuperscriptℝ𝑑1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1}} ‖A−yw⊤‖22+λ​‖w‖1superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptywtop22𝜆subscriptnormw1\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{y}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{w}\|_{1} (24)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. w⊤​w=1,superscriptwtopw1\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=1,

where y=AwyAw\textbf{y}=\textbf{A}\textbf{w} is the approximation of the projected data Aw. With such formulation, we are able to take advantage of temporarily treating y as a known part when computing w, thus simplifying the optimization problem.

Similarly, we decompose ‖A−yw⊤‖22superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptywtop22\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{y}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2} into K𝐾K parts by

‖A−yw⊤‖22=∑i=1K‖Ai−y~i​w⊤‖22,superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptywtop22superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖subscript~y𝑖superscriptwtop22\displaystyle\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{y}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{K}\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\tilde{\textbf{y}}_{i}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}, (25)

where y~i=Ai​wsubscript~y𝑖superscriptA𝑖w\tilde{\textbf{y}}_{i}=\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}. Then, we can reformulate (24) as a consensus optimization problem

minw1,⋯,wK∈ℝd×1subscriptsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1}} ∑i=1K‖Ai−yi​wi⊤‖22+λ​‖z‖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖subscripty𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top22𝜆subscriptnormz1\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{y}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{z}\|_{1} (26)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. wi⊤​wi=1​ and wi=z,∀i,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptw𝑖topsubscriptw𝑖1subscript and w𝑖zfor-all𝑖\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{w}_{i}=1\text{ and }\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{z},\forall i,

where w1,⋯,wK∈ℝd×1subscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑1\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1} are local parameter for each worker, z∈ℝd×1zsuperscriptℝ𝑑1\textbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1} is the consensus parameter, and yi=Ai​wi,∀isubscripty𝑖superscriptA𝑖subscriptw𝑖for-all𝑖\textbf{y}_{i}=\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i},\ \forall i, is the approximation of the projected data Ai​wisuperscriptA𝑖subscriptw𝑖\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i}. In practice, the approximation is performed using the loading from the previous iteration.

By introducing dual variables ui∈ℝd×1,i=1,…,k,formulae-sequencesubscriptu𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑1𝑖1…𝑘\textbf{u}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1},\ i=1,\dots,k, for the equality constraint, we obtain the augmented Lagrangian,

ℒρ​({wi,ui}i=1K,z)=subscriptℒ𝜌superscriptsubscriptsubscriptw𝑖subscriptu𝑖𝑖1𝐾zabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\rho}(\{\textbf{w}_{i},\textbf{u}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K},\textbf{z})= ∑i=1K(∥Ai−yiwi⊤∥22+ui⊤(wi−z)\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{K}\left(\vphantom{\frac{\rho}{2}}\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{y}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\textbf{u}_{i}^{\top}(\textbf{w}_{i}-\textbf{z})\right. (27)
+ρ2∥wi−z∥22)+λ∥z∥1,\displaystyle\left.\vphantom{\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{y}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|\textbf{w}_{i}-\textbf{z}\|_{2}^{2}\right)+\lambda\|\textbf{z}\|_{1},

where ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 is a penalty parameter. The general ADMM algorithm for FASPCA is conducted in Algorithm 6 by minimizing ℒρ​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝜌⋅\mathcal{L}_{\rho}(\cdot) w.r.t. wi,z,uisubscriptw𝑖zsubscriptu𝑖\textbf{w}_{i},\textbf{z},\textbf{u}_{i} alternately.

In the z-update phase, we replicate the approach used in problem (6). This involves calculating the minimum of ℒρ​({wi,ui}i=1K,z)subscriptℒ𝜌superscriptsubscriptsubscriptw𝑖subscriptu𝑖𝑖1𝐾z\mathcal{L}_{\rho}(\{\textbf{w}_{i},\textbf{u}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K},\textbf{z}) with respect to z by employing Algorithm 2, adhering to a consistent update pattern.

Next, let us introduce how to compute wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} in Algorithm 6. Given fixed yisubscripty𝑖\textbf{y}_{i}, uisubscriptu𝑖\textbf{u}_{i} and z, the optimization of ℒρ​({wi,ui}i=1K,z)subscriptℒ𝜌superscriptsubscriptsubscriptw𝑖subscriptu𝑖𝑖1𝐾z\mathcal{L}_{\rho}(\{\textbf{w}_{i},\textbf{u}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K},\textbf{z}) over wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} is

minwi∈ℝd×1subscriptsubscriptw𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1}} ‖Ai−yi​wi⊤‖22+ui⊤​wi+ρ2​‖wi−z‖22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖subscripty𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top22superscriptsubscriptu𝑖topsubscriptw𝑖𝜌2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptw𝑖z22\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{y}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\textbf{u}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{w}_{i}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|\textbf{w}_{i}-\textbf{z}\|_{2}^{2} (28)
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t. wi⊤​wi=1.superscriptsubscriptw𝑖topsubscriptw𝑖1\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{w}_{i}=1.

Set f​(wi):=‖Ai−yi​wi⊤‖22+ui⊤​wi+ρ​‖wi−z‖22/2assign𝑓subscriptw𝑖superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptA𝑖subscripty𝑖superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top22superscriptsubscriptu𝑖topsubscriptw𝑖𝜌superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptw𝑖z222f(\textbf{w}_{i}):=\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{y}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\textbf{u}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{w}_{i}+\rho\|\textbf{w}_{i}-\textbf{z}\|_{2}^{2}/2. To find the minimum of f​(wi)𝑓subscriptw𝑖f(\textbf{w}_{i}), suppose ∂f​(wi)/∂wi=0𝑓subscriptw𝑖subscriptw𝑖0\partial f(\textbf{w}_{i})/\partial\textbf{w}_{i}=0, then we have

wi=2​(Ai)⊤​yi−ui+ρ​z2​yi⊤​yi+ρ.subscriptw𝑖2superscriptsuperscriptA𝑖topsubscripty𝑖subscriptu𝑖𝜌z2superscriptsubscripty𝑖topsubscripty𝑖𝜌\displaystyle\textbf{w}_{i}=\frac{2(\textbf{A}^{i})^{\top}\textbf{y}_{i}-\textbf{u}_{i}+\rho\textbf{z}}{2\textbf{y}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{y}_{i}+\rho}.

To fit the orthonormality constraint w⊤​w=1superscriptwtopw1\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=1, we directly normalize wisubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i} as follows

wi=wi‖wi‖2.subscriptw𝑖subscriptw𝑖subscriptnormsubscriptw𝑖2\displaystyle\textbf{w}_{i}=\frac{\textbf{w}_{i}}{\|\textbf{w}_{i}\|_{2}}. (29)

III-E Deflation method for FASPCA

Similarly, we extend the FASPCA to compute the r𝑟rth loading with the presence of the first r−1𝑟1r-1 loadings. The main distinction between FSSPCA and FASPCA is that the former computes multiple loadings simultaneously, while the latter computes one loading at a time. Therefore, we adapt Algorithm 4 and modify Step 9 for FASPCA by:

zj←zj/‖zj‖2.←subscriptz𝑗subscriptz𝑗subscriptnormsubscriptz𝑗2\displaystyle\textbf{z}_{j}\leftarrow\textbf{z}_{j}/\|\textbf{z}_{j}\|_{2}. (30)

Suppose we have r−1𝑟1r-1 loadings {zi}i=1r−1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptz𝑖𝑖1𝑟1\{\textbf{z}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r-1} and intend to compute the r𝑟rth loading, the problem is formulated as

minw1,⋯,wK∈ℝd×1subscriptsubscriptw1⋯subscriptw𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1}} ∑i=1K‖(Ai)D−yiD​wi⊤‖22+λ​‖z‖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsuperscriptA𝑖𝐷superscriptsubscripty𝑖𝐷superscriptsubscriptw𝑖top22𝜆subscriptnormz1\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}\|(\textbf{A}^{i})^{D}-\textbf{y}_{i}^{D}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{z}\|_{1} (31)

where (Ai)D=Ai​GsuperscriptsuperscriptA𝑖𝐷superscriptA𝑖G(\textbf{A}^{i})^{D}=\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{G}, yiD=(Ai)D​wisuperscriptsubscripty𝑖𝐷superscriptsuperscriptA𝑖𝐷subscriptw𝑖\textbf{y}_{i}^{D}=(\textbf{A}^{i})^{D}\textbf{w}_{i}, and G=∏i=1r−1(I−zi​zi⊤)∈ℝd×dGsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑟1Isubscriptz𝑖superscriptsubscriptz𝑖topsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\textbf{G}=\prod_{i=1}^{r-1}(\textbf{I}-\textbf{z}_{i}\textbf{z}_{i}^{\top})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} lie in the orthogonal complement space of {zi}i=1r−1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptz𝑖𝑖1𝑟1\{\textbf{z}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r-1}. Since G is a orthogonal projection matrix, we have G=G⊤GsuperscriptGtop\textbf{G}=\textbf{G}^{\top} and G⊤​G=GsuperscriptGtopGG\textbf{G}^{\top}\textbf{G}=\textbf{G}. Hence, by (32), we can ensure wi⊤​Gwi=1superscriptsubscriptw𝑖topsubscriptGw𝑖1\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\textbf{G}\textbf{w}_{i}=1.

IV Experiment

In the federated learning framework, non-IID (non-Independently and Identically Distributed) data distribution across nodes is a critical concern, as it can significantly reduce both the accuracy and convergence rate [32, 38]. Real-world scenarios often exhibit data skews and imbalances among participating workers due to a variety of factors such as user behavior, data collection methods, and other domain-specific influences. To evaluate the performance of our proposed methods, FSSPCA and FASPCA, we conducted experiments on four distinct datasets: IID synthetic data, non-IID synthetic data, IID real data, and non-IID real data. These evaluations were performed on a universally accessible laptop with an Intel Core i5-8250U CPU and 8 GB of RAM, operating without the assistance of a GPU. All algorithms were implemented using the Python programming environment.

IV-A Experiments on IID synthetic data

In the following experiments, we assess FSSPCA and FASPCA using synthetic data sampled from a zero-mean multivariate normal distribution with a covariance matrix 𝚺∈ℝ500×500𝚺superscriptℝ500500\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\in\mathbb{R}^{500\times 500} that consists of sparse eigenvectors and split the dataset into K𝐾K parts to evaluate the performance of our methods in different distributed systems. Following [9, 24], we construct 𝚺=VDV⊤𝚺superscriptVDVtop\boldsymbol{\Sigma}=\textbf{V}\textbf{D}\textbf{V}^{\top}, where V∈ℝ500×500Vsuperscriptℝ500500\textbf{V}\in\mathbb{R}^{500\times 500} is an orthogonal matrix whose columns are eigenvectors of 𝚺𝚺\boldsymbol{\Sigma} and D∈ℝ500×500Dsuperscriptℝ500500\textbf{D}\in\mathbb{R}^{500\times 500} is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal elements are eigenvalues of 𝚺𝚺\boldsymbol{\Sigma}. We set the first two columns of V as the ground truth for sparse loadings, specifically setting the first 10 elements of the first column and the second 10 elements of the second column to 110110\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}, while all other elements are set to 0. The remaining columns of V are random samples from a uniform distribution over [0, 1). The first two eigenvalues of D are set to 400 and 300, respectively, and the rest are set to 1. Our aim is to recover the first two significant eigenvectors, denoted as V​s​o​lV𝑠𝑜𝑙\textbf{V}{sol}, and performance is evaluated by the recovery error ϵ=‖zz⊤−Vs​o​l​Vs​o​l⊤‖F2italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptzztopsubscriptV𝑠𝑜𝑙superscriptsubscriptV𝑠𝑜𝑙top𝐹2\epsilon=\|\textbf{z}\textbf{z}^{\top}-\textbf{V}_{sol}\textbf{V}_{sol}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}, where z is the outcome of our methods.

Firstly, we demonstrate that parameters from each worker become increasingly similar with each iteration to attain a consensus model parameter. To evaluate this, we set K=10𝐾10K=10 and compute the pairwise cosine similarity of all workers’ parameters, and then average their absolute values. Fig. 2 illustrates that with an increasing number of iterations, the average value approaches 1. In other words, the parameters from each worker will become more and more similar to each other, which satisfies the constraint of the prime problem for FASPCA (26) and FSSPCA (6).

Next, we split the synthetic dataset into K𝐾K parts to evaluate the recovery error of our methods with different numbers of data owners, where K=1,3,5,10𝐾13510K=1,3,5,10. As shown in Fig. 3, regardless of the value of K𝐾K, as the λ𝜆\lambda or λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1} increase, the recovery error approaches 0. In other words, our methods yield outcomes that closely resemble the ground truth Vs​o​lsubscriptV𝑠𝑜𝑙\textbf{V}_{sol}. Hence, we conclude that our proposed models FASPCA and FSSPCA are capable of obtaining sparse loadings under the FL framework.

IV-B Experiments on IID Real data

Wisconsin Diagnostic Breast Cancer Dataset (WDBC) [39] is a well-known dataset for the classification task. This dataset contains 569 instances with 31 features. The primary goal of SPCA is to identify important features. To evaluate the performance of our proposed models, we choose the last 30 features of WDBC, excluding the ID number. We augmented it with 800 randomly generated features from a uniform distribution over [0, 1) to create a new dataset WDBC⋆∈ℝ569×830superscriptWDBC⋆superscriptℝ569830\text{WDBC}^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{569\times 830}. In the following experiments, our goal is to identify 2 sparse loadings. We demonstrate that our proposed models can effectively identify important features by shrinking the weights of the added random features to zero or close to zero.

Firstly, we show the effectiveness of adding the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm smoothing terms for FSSPCA. As shown in Fig. 4, when λ1=10subscript𝜆110\lambda_{1}=10, which means that we activate the smoothing function term r​(wi)𝑟subscriptw𝑖r(\textbf{w}_{i}), the convergence behavior is far better than the case of λ1=0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}=0. That is to say, adding the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm smoothing terms significantly improves convergence.

Since one of the primary purposes of SPCA is to facilitate interpretability through sparse loadings, we assess the result of the purposed methods. In Fig. 5, for both FASPCA and FSSPCA, we observed that all the weights associated with the added random features lie in [−0.1,0.1]0.10.1[-0.1,0.1]. Additionally, 27%percent\% and 35%percent\% of the weights corresponding to original features of FASPCA and FSSPCA fell within [−0.1,0.1]0.10.1[-0.1,0.1], respectively. Moreover, for i∈{1,2,⋯,10}𝑖12⋯10i\in\{1,2,\cdots,10\}, we noticed that the percentages of small values, falling within [−10i,10i]superscript10𝑖superscript10𝑖[-10^{i},10^{i}], of added random features are higher than the original features. These findings confirm that both FASPCA and FSSPCA provide more interpretable results and can effectively identify important features in the dataset.

As shown in Table I, no matter FASPCA or FSSPCA, the reconstruction errors of our proposed models are close to PCA and the ℓ0subscriptℓ0\ell_{0}-norm of our proposed models are less than PCA. Thus, our proposed model can indeed attain loading sparsity. Additionally, while FASPCA is faster in terms of computation time, FSSPCA requires fewer iterations, almost half that of FASPCA. In our experiments, we assume negligible transmission costs between workers and the master. However, in scenarios with significant transmission costs, FSSPCA may offer advantages over FASPCA.

IV-C Experiments on non-IID synthetic data

In the third experiment, we evaluate our proposed model on non-IID synthetic data. The data is generated in a manner similar to the IID synthetic dataset, with eigenvalues and the first two eigenvectors remaining consistent across all workers. However, for each worker, the remaining eigenvectors are uniquely generated as random samples from a normal distribution N​(0,σi)𝑁0subscript𝜎𝑖N(0,\sigma_{i}), and σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} is independently sampled from a uniform distribution over [0, 1) for each worker.

As demonstrated in Fig. 6, the trends observed in non-IID synthetic data are consistent with those in IID synthetic data. Specifically, as the number of iterations increases, the average value converges toward 1. This pattern demonstrates that the parameters from each worker become increasingly aligned, thereby meeting the constraints of the primary problems as defined for both FASPCA (26) and FSSPCA (6). Moreover, the recovery errors for FASPCA and FSSPCA were 0.0855 and 0.02466, respectively. Both of which are close to zero, indicating an effective approach towards the ground truth Vs​o​lsubscriptV𝑠𝑜𝑙\textbf{V}_{sol}. The robustness of our proposed methods in both IID and non-IID settings highlights their effectiveness and broad applicability within the federated learning framework.

IV-D Experiments on non-IID Real data

In the fourth experiment, we assess the performance of our proposed model on non-IID real data. Similar to Subsection B, we retain the last 30 features of the WDBC dataset, but introduce modifications to the additional 800 random features. These 800 features are now uniquely allocated to each participating worker. For each worker, the allocated features are generated using a normal distribution with a mean of zero and a variance sampled from a uniform distribution over [0, 1). The remaining features are rendered sparse, with 80% being exactly 0 and 20% non-zero values generated from a uniform distribution over [0, 1). With this generating scheme, each worker may return the local model with some non-zero weights associated with the allocated parts, while the other workers returning sparse results.

Referring to Fig. 7, it is evident that for both FASPCA and FSSPCA, the weights of the added random features fall within the range of [−0.01,0.01]0.010.01[-0.01,0.01]. In contrast, 55%percent\% of the original feature weights for FASPCA and 30%percent\% for FSSPCA lie within the [−0.1,0.1]0.10.1[-0.1,0.1] range. Moreover, for i𝑖i in the set {1,2,…,10}12…10\{1,2,\ldots,10\}, the proportions of smaller values that fall within the bounds of [−10i,10i]superscript10𝑖superscript10𝑖[-10^{i},10^{i}] are notably higher for the added random features compared with the original features. Another critical aspect to consider is the reconstruction error. The reconstruction error for PCA itself stands at 236.4406, while for FASPCA and FSSPCA, it stands at 242.4147 and 236.9857, respectively. These close values indicate that both FASPCA and FSSPCA perform comparably to traditional PCA. These results show that both FASPCA and FSSPCA work well in identifying important features and provide easily interpretable outcomes, even when applied to the non-IID dataset.

V Conclusion and Future Work

We have introduced two innovative approaches: Federated Approximation Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FASPCA) and Federated Smoothing Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FSSPCA). These methods are designed to tackle the Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA) challenge within a distributed framework. They enable model training on client-side devices, preserving privacy by keeping data localized. Instead of transmitting raw data to a central server, only model updates are exchanged, significantly enhancing data security. We have also incorporated the least squares approximation in the PCA component to reduce computational complexity without compromising accuracy. In specific scenarios, such as anomaly detection, where only a single loading is required, FASPCA demonstrates remarkable efficiency due to its rapid computation. When multiple loadings are necessary, the deflation technique is employed to map the data to the orthogonal complement space of the leading component. Our experiments, conducted on synthetic and WDBC⋆superscriptWDBC⋆\text{WDBC}^{\star} datasets, underscore the exceptional performance of both FASPCA and FSSPCA in obtaining sparse loadings within distributed systems. Furthermore, these methods effectively extract crucial features while accommodating non-IID (non-Independently and Identically Distributed) random features.

In our future research endeavors, we intend to explore the integration of cryptographic techniques, such as differential privacy, to further enhance data security and privacy within the federated learning framework.
